rev.comment: add details to LEAD and reorganize a bit.
rev.diff:
Line 17: Line 17:
'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}} and {{lse|GGEA}}) is an [[United States|American]] [[public company|public corporation]], specializing in [[Internet search]] and [[online advertising]]. The company had 10,674 full-time employees as of [[December 31]], [[2006]], and is based in [[Mountain View, California]]. Google's mission statement is "to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful."<ref>"[http://www.google.com/corporate/ Google Corporate Information: Company Overview]." ''[[Google]].'' Retrieved on [[January 6]], [[2007]].</ref>
'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}} and {{lse|GGEA}}) is an [[United States|American]] [[public company|public corporation]], specializing in [[Internet search]] and [[online advertising]]. The company had 10,674 full-time employees as of [[December 31]], [[2006]], and is based in [[Mountain View, California]]. Google's mission statement is "to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful."<ref>"[http://www.google.com/corporate/ Google Corporate Information: Company Overview]." ''[[Google]].'' Retrieved on [[January 6]], [[2007]].</ref>
â
Google was co-founded by [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] while they were students at [[Stanford University]], and the company was first incorporated as a [[privately held company]] on [[September 7]] [[1998]]. Google's initial public offering took place on [[August 19]], [[2004]], raising [[United States Dollar|$]]1.67 billion, making it worth $23 billion.<ref name="washpost">Webb, Cynthia L. "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A14939-2004Aug19.html Google's IPO: Grate Expectations]." ''[[Washington Post]].'' [[August 19]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> The company grew rapidly since its IPO, acquiring smaller companies such as Writely, [[JotSpot]], and online video sharing site [[YouTube]] in [[2006]], and moving into the office software market with [[Google Apps|Google Apps Premium Edition]] in [[2007]].
+
Google was co-founded by [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] while they were students at [[Stanford University]], and the company was first incorporated as a [[privately held company]] on [[September 7]] [[1998]]. Google's initial public offering took place on [[August 19]], [[2004]], raising [[United States Dollar|$]]1.67 billion, making it worth $23 billion.<ref name="washpost">Webb, Cynthia L. "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A14939-2004Aug19.html Google's IPO: Grate Expectations]." ''[[Washington Post]].'' [[August 19]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> The company grew rapidly since its IPO, acquiring smaller companies such as Writely, [[JotSpot]], and online video sharing site [[YouTube]] in [[2006]], and moving into the office software market with [[Google Apps|Google Apps Premium Edition]] in [[2007]]. Additionally, Google is also involved in many cooperational partnerships with other corporations and organizations, such as [[NASA]], [[Sun Microsystems]], [[Time Warner]]'s [[America Online]], and [[NewsCorp]]'s [[MySpace]]
  +   +
Like most large corporations, Google's businesses have drawn some [[History of Google#Criticism and controversy|controversy]], such as [[copyright]] disputes in its [[Google Book Search|book search project]], or accusations of [[Censorship by Google|censorship]] of search results as it works with countries such as [[France]], [[Germany]], and [[China]]. Additionally, in the [[September 11, 2001 attacks|post September 11 era]], several governments have raised concerns about the security risks posed by geographic details provided by [[Google Earth|Google Earth's]] satellite imaging.<ref name="satimgs">Sharma, Dinesh C. "[http://news.com.com/Indian+president+rails+against+Google+Earth/2100-1028_3-5896888.html?part=rss&tag=5896888&subj=news Indian president warns against Google Earth]." ''[http://www.cnet.com/ c net].'' [[October 17]], [[2005]]. Retrieved on [[July 23]], [[2006]].</ref>
Google is particularly known for its relaxed corporate culture. Their corporate philosophy is based on many casual principles including, "You can make money without doing evil", "You can be serious without a suit," and "Work should be challenging and the challenge should be fun." This relaxed culture can also be seen externally through their holiday variations of the [[Google logo]], as well as their various [[Google's hoaxes|hoaxes and April Fool's Day jokes]].
Google is particularly known for its relaxed corporate culture. Their corporate philosophy is based on many casual principles including, "You can make money without doing evil", "You can be serious without a suit," and "Work should be challenging and the challenge should be fun." This relaxed culture can also be seen externally through their holiday variations of the [[Google logo]], as well as their various [[Google's hoaxes|hoaxes and April Fool's Day jokes]].
The name "Google" originated from a misspelling of "[[googol]],"<ref>Koller, David. "[http://graphics.stanford.edu/~dk/google_name_origin.html Origin of the name, "Google."] ''[[Stanford University]].'' January, 2004.</ref><ref>Hanley, Rachael. "[http://daily.stanford.org/article/2003/2/12/fromGoogolToGoogle From Googol to Google: Co-founder returns]." ''[[The Stanford Daily]].'' [[February 12]], [[2003]]. Retrieved on [[July 14]], [[2006]].</ref> which refers to 10<sup>100</sup> (the number represented by a 1 followed by one-hundred zeros). Having found its way increasingly into everyday language, the verb, "[[Google (verb)|google]]," was added to the ''[[Merriam-Webster|Merriam Webster Collegiate Dictionary]]'' and the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' in [[2006]], meaning, "to use the Google search engine to obtain information on the Internet."<ref>Harris, Scott D. "[http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/business/14985574.htm Dictionary adds verb: to google]." ''[[San Jose Mercury News]].'' [[July 7]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 7]], [[2006]].</ref><ref>Bylund, Anders. "[http://msnbc.msn.com/id/13720643/ To Google or Not to Google]." ''[[The Motley Fool]] via [[MSNBC]].'' [[July 5]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 7]], [[2006]].</ref>
The name "Google" originated from a misspelling of "[[googol]],"<ref>Koller, David. "[http://graphics.stanford.edu/~dk/google_name_origin.html Origin of the name, "Google."] ''[[Stanford University]].'' January, 2004.</ref><ref>Hanley, Rachael. "[http://daily.stanford.org/article/2003/2/12/fromGoogolToGoogle From Googol to Google: Co-founder returns]." ''[[The Stanford Daily]].'' [[February 12]], [[2003]]. Retrieved on [[July 14]], [[2006]].</ref> which refers to 10<sup>100</sup> (the number represented by a 1 followed by one-hundred zeros). Having found its way increasingly into everyday language, the verb, "[[Google (verb)|google]]," was added to the ''[[Merriam-Webster|Merriam Webster Collegiate Dictionary]]'' and the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' in [[2006]], meaning, "to use the Google search engine to obtain information on the Internet."<ref>Harris, Scott D. "[http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/business/14985574.htm Dictionary adds verb: to google]." ''[[San Jose Mercury News]].'' [[July 7]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 7]], [[2006]].</ref><ref>Bylund, Anders. "[http://msnbc.msn.com/id/13720643/ To Google or Not to Google]." ''[[The Motley Fool]] via [[MSNBC]].'' [[July 5]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 7]], [[2006]].</ref>
â   â
Like most large corporations, Google's businesses have drawn some [[History of Google#Criticism and controversy|controversy]], such as [[copyright]] disputes in its [[Google Book Search|book search project]], or accusations of [[Censorship by Google|censorship]] of search results as it works with countries such as [[France]], [[Germany]], and [[China]]. Additionally, in the [[September 11, 2001 attacks|post September 11 era]], several governments have raised concerns about the security risks posed by geographic details provided by [[Google Earth|Google Earth's]] satellite imaging.<ref name="satimgs">Sharma, Dinesh C. "[http://news.com.com/Indian+president+rails+against+Google+Earth/2100-1028_3-5896888.html?part=rss&tag=5896888&subj=news Indian president warns against Google Earth]."
